patient_information: Age: 34 years Sex: male Country of origin: Thailand Travel history: recent travel to Thailand, arrived in Germany only 3 days prior Comorbidities: none reported Immunosuppression: highly immunosuppressed with a CD4 cell count of 2/μL (normal range: 500–1000/μL) Allergy history: no allergy history provided
chief_complaint: Duration: 2-week history of fever Symptoms: fever, unexplained weight loss, lymphadenopathy and a papular rash
history_of_present_illness: Timeline: 3-month history of wasting Key symptoms: generalized non-pruritic rash predominantly on the face and trunk, mild hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy Severity pattern: progressive worsening over time
exposure_and_epidemiology: Residence travel: lives in Thailand and arrived in Germany only 3 days prior to visit friends Vectors animals: no animal or water/food risks reported, no sick contacts Season outbreak context: travel to an endemic area Occupation: not specified
vitals: Temperature: 38.2°C (100.76°F) Other vitals: conjunctivae pale, body mass index of 14kg/m²
physical_exam: Findings: febrile patient with a generalized non-pruritic rash predominantly on the face and trunk, mild hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy Other findings: no focal neurologic deficits or respiratory distress described
labs_and_diagnostics: Full blood count: WBC 2.1 × 109/L (reference range 4–10), haemoglobin 9.8g/dL (13–16), platelets 110 × 109/L (150–350) C-reactive protein: C-reactive protein 150mg/L (<5) Microbiological work-up: blood culture, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, skin biopsy, lymph node biopsy Pathological work-up: histopathology of the lymph node biopsy showed multiple yeast-like structures
differential_diagnosis: Considered: HIV infection, CMV and EBV infection, disseminated tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria, melioidosis, bartonellosis (bacillary angiomatosis), fungal infections Justification: each of these conditions alone should warrant HIV testing; fever, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and rash are common in these diseases
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: intravenous liposomal amphotericin B followed by oral itraconazole Response: fever resolved on follow-up, gaining weight Complications: no complications documented Outcome: recovery
final_diagnosis: Disease name short: Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis) Confirmation method: positive blood culture and skin biopsy showing Talaromyces (Penicillium) marneffei Evidence: umbilicated papular rash, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia
